fullDescription:
The Olympic Games
were far more than athletic competitions - they were a sacred festival honoring Zeus, king of the gods,
held every four years at his great sanctuary in Olympia. For five days, the Greek world paused in sacred truce (ekecheiria) as athletes,
spectators, and pilgrims gathered to witness human excellence dedicated to divine glory. The games combined religious ritual, artistic
performance, and physical contests, embodying the Greek ideal of kalokagathia
(beauty and goodness united).

The most prominent foundation myth tells of Pelops defeating King Oenomaus in a chariot race to win Princess Hippodamia, establishing funeral games that evolved into the Olympics.
